segments.text: Translation.
Yehuda realized he was in trouble and didn't really know what to do.
He felt so uncomfortable asking her to leave.
What would happen?
But he had told her from the start that it was just until she was released, and she herself always said, just for now.
It became a kind of joke between them when they met, but without them noticing, a year and a half had already passed, a month after she was discharged from her military service.
He passed by the pink house and saw her in the garden, leaning over her flowers.
Something stopped him from approaching her.
He had quietly adapted to visiting the house when she was in the army and he was alone.
a kind of Kong always spread over him, brought by the good energies that filled the house.
He smiled to himself.
He didn't really believe in energies, mysticism and such, but something about this girl, this house and the story around them made him feel the telepathy that existed between her and her mother.
And when she wasn't there, he looked deep into Lucy's eyes in the portrait, gazing back at him, promising her in his heart that everything was okay with her daughter.
Something softened in him about this story, breaking the cynicism that tried to surface from time to time.

Sometimes he would turn on the sprinklers, sit in the armchair with a beer or a glass of water, and simply enjoy the house, glancing at the book lying next to the armchair, waiting for him from the previous week and knowing that this arrangement with her excited and delighted him.
He and his wife intended to move to London for a while, maybe permanently.
It wasn't clear yet.
His wife's family offered him to join their flourishing real estate business there, which was very appealing to them.
He had already sold his heavy equipment to one of the contractors, handing over the remaining work contracts too.
He had several interested buyers for the hotel houses.
No doubt, it's easier to sell when it's well maintained.
But without realizing it, he put them off with back and forth for over a month, unable to bring himself to talk to her, truly anxious about that conversation.
A year and a half, she was there.

A few months earlier, she had called him and said she now had an arrangement with some permanent tenants and she wanted to start transferring him an additional monthly amount beyond the lease payment.
I'll keep a little money for living expenses, like pocket money.
I ask that you agree and not argue, because otherwise I can't stay here, and this way I feel like I'm managing the hotel for you.
And indeed, once a month a sum of money entered his account.
Not large, but quite decent, especially considering that he didn't lift a finger to get it.
And now what?
What would he do?
What would he tell her?
He knew he had to approach and talk to her, that he couldn't postpone it any longer, and he prepared a speech gently explaining that the just for now was ending, that there was no other choice.
On Friday afternoon, he made his way to her at a brisk pace, determined to end the story.
But as he approached the house, he began to feel butterflies in his stomach.
The door was wide open and the floor was still damp from cleaning.
He searched for her with his eyes and didn't find her.
Suddenly, he noticed her through the glass doors, taking the porch chairs off the tables and putting them back in their place.
He went out to her and when she noticed him, a warm smile lit up her face.

It took a second, no more than a second, and he froze in place a few steps from her, completely stunned, realizing that what he was seeing was her pregnant belly, which was indeed small, but she was pregnant.
She was wearing shorts and a wide t-shirt, but still he had no doubt.
The girl was pregnant.
The speech he had rehearsed earlier disappeared from his mind in an instant.
There was no way he would tell her to leave now.
Hey, Yehuda, how are you?
You're a bit surprised, right?
Well, it happens in the best families.
She laughed in embarrassment.
Come, let's sit and drink something, and I'll update you.
They sat in the garden.
It was afternoon.
The light was beautiful.
And the garden was embracing.
Yehuda asked for.
A cup of coffee.
And she returned with coffee and homemade cookies on the side.
And for herself, she filled the large beer glass with water.
That's the only thing she has.
She's always thirsty for water.
Only then did he notice the charming dog sprawled on a mat at the entrance.
That's something new, he thought.
She noticed his gaze.
This is Blue, my gatekeeper, she said with a smile.
He showed up one day, early in the morning.
And since then he came every time I came here and disappeared when I returned to the army.
Very strange.
It's like someone sent him to look after me.
Maybe mom.
But since I was discharged and I'm here all the time, he agreed to move inside and stay.
She sent a warm look at Blue, then turned her head to Yehuda.
Look, I have a boyfriend, an officer from my unit, and this pregnancy is from him.
But he's on some secret mission they don't talk about, and I'll just have to wait for him to return.
In any case, it's a baby of great and true love.
She was surprised to feel so comfortable telling him so openly about the situation and getting into such intimate details without any hesitation.
And maybe it's a girl, Yehuda smiled.
No, it's a boy for sure.
I really feel it.
She didn't smile.
She was entirely serious when she said that.
We haven't met in a long time.
I saw you passing by and thanks for turning on the sprinklers.
I don't think I've seen you for almost half a year.
Can you believe I'd been here for a year and a half?
It's nice you came.
I hope everything is okay with you.
Yehuda took a deep breath.
The truth is, I came to tell you that we plan to move to London in two or three months, joining my wife's family and their real estate business.
It sounds wonderful to us and we really feel like a change.
He didn't want to reveal to her the failed attempts he and his wife had to get pregnant, which was a catalyst for this desired change, especially not now for a moment.
She was speechless.
You mean you're going to sell the house now?
Is that why you came?
She couldn't overcome the tremble in her voice.
What would she do with an eight month belly?
Where could she move?
And how could she make a living with a baby when it was unclear when his father planned to return for a moment?
She felt on the verge of fainting, sensing her heartbeat pounding wildly inside her, unable to control her voice.
Yehuda lifted his eyes to her and saw and heard everything.
The pallor that spread over her, the trembling voice that emerged from her.
He placed his hand on hers.
Nothing urgent.
It can wait.
You're already sending me payment every month, and if the money from the sale were lying in the bank, it wouldn't do anything.
So don't worry.
We'll wait and see what happens.
First, your baby should arrive and everything should go smoothly.
And then his father should return.
And when everything settles, we can also finish this adventure.
The lump in her throat released.
Air entered her lungs again and tears of relief filled her eyes.
I was scared, she said.
For a moment, I didn't know what I would do.
Are you sure, Yehuda?
Yes, yes, he replied, knowing there was nothing to discuss.
He wouldn't make her leave before giving birth.
Tell me whether you do.
In a month and a bit, I'm in the eighth month.
Is this what the eighth month looks like?
He laughed.
You're, as they say, a string with a knot.
Are you feeling well?
Yes, excellent.
Honestly, a few extra kilograms actually suit you.
Above your thinness.
Your cheeks are also slightly flushed.
She laughed a free laugh.
A moment ago, they were pale as a sheet in fear.
Now the flush has returned to the cheeks.
You'll need to give me all your details in London, the address and the phone number, and I'll write and update you on what's happening here.
Yehuda Rose ran a hand over her head, shook her hand as usual and said, We'll come by to say goodbye before we travel.
He went on his way, surprisingly calm, and at peace with the decision he made.
There's just one problem.
How will he?
Tell his wife about the child in the girl's belly while they themselves have been trying for almost three years and nothing helps.
Her heart will ache when she hears this.
